people shouted The voice of a god and not of a man twenty three And immediately an angel of the Lord smote him because he gave not glory to God and he was eaten by worms and expired twenty four But the word of God grew and multiplied twenty five And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem having performed the service taking with them also John who was surnamed Mark XIII AND there were at Antioch in the church that was there prophets and teachers Barnabas and Simeon who was called Niger and Lucius the Cyrenean and Manaen the foster brother of Herod the tetrarch and Saul two And while they were ministering to the Lord and fasting the Holy Spirit said Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul unto the work to which I have called them three Then having fasted and prayed and laid their hands on them they sent them away four They therefore being sent forth by the Holy Spirit came down to Seleucia and from thence they sailed away to Cyprus five And having come to Salamis they preached the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews and they had also John as an assistant six And having gone through the island to Paphos they found a certain Magian a Jewish false prophet whose name was Bar jesus seven who was with the proconsul of the country Sergius Paulus an intelligent man He having called for Barnabas and Saul desired to hear the word of God eight But Elymas the Magian for so his name is interpreted withstood them seeking to turn away the proconsul from the faith nine Then Saul who is also called Paul filled with the Holy Spirit fixed his eyes on him ten and said O full of all deceit and all wickedness child of the Devil enemy of all righteousness wilt thou not cease to pervert the right ways of the Lord eleven And now behold the hand of the Lord is upon thee and thou shalt be blind not seeing the sun for a season And immediately there fell on him a mist and darkness and going about he sought persons to lead him by the hand twelve Then the proconsul seeing what was done believed being astonished at the teaching of the Lord thirteen And Paul and his companions having put to sea from Paphos came to Perga in Pamphylia and John departing from them returned to Jerusalem fourteen But they going on from Perga came to Antioch in Pisidia and entering into the synagogue on the sabbath day they sat down fifteen And after the reading of the law and the prophets the rulers of the synagogue sent to them saying Men brethren if ye have any word of exhortation for the people speak sixteen And Paul arose and beckoning with the hand said Men of Israel and ye that fear God hearken seventeen The God of this people of Israel chose our fathers and he exalted the people in their sojourn in the land of Egypt and with a high arm he brought them out of it eighteen And about the time of forty years he nourished them thirteen eighteen in the wilderness nineteen And having destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan he gave them their land as a possession twenty about four hundred and fifty years And after that he gave judges until Samuel the prophet twenty one And afterward they desired a king and God gave them Saul the Son of Kish a man of the tribe of Benjamin for forty years twenty two And having removed him he raised up for them David to be their king to whom also he gave testimony saying I found David the son of Jesse a man after my own heart who will do all my will twenty three Of the seed of this man God according to promise raised up to Israel a Savior Jesus twenty four John having first preached before his entrance the immersion of repentance to all the people of Israel twenty five Now as John was finishing his course he said Whom do ye suppose me to be I am not he But behold there comes one after me the sandal of whose feet I am not worthy to loose twenty six Men brethren children of the race of Abraham and whoever among you fears God to you the word of this salvation was sent forth twenty seven For they who dwell at Jerusalem and their rulers not knowing him nor the voices of the prophets which are read every sabbath day fulfilled them in condemning him twenty eight And though they found no cause of death they demanded of Pilate that he should be slain twenty nine And when they had fulfilled all the things written of him they took him down from the tree and laid him in a tomb thirty But God raised him from the dead thirty one And he was seen for many days by those who came up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem who are now his witnesses unto the people thirty two And we declare to you glad tidings of the promise made to the fathers thirty three that God has fulfilled this to us their children in raising Jesus as also it is written in the second psalm thirteen thirty three Thou art my Son I this day have begotten thee thirty four And that he raised him up from the dead to return no more to corruption he has thus spoken I will give to you the holy the sure promises of David thirty five Wherefore also in another psalm he says Thou wilt not suffer thy Holy One to see corruption thirty six For David having served his own generation according to the purpose of God fell asleep and was added to his fathers and saw corruption thirty seven But he whom God raised saw not corruption thirty eight Be it known to you therefore men brethren that remission of sins through this man is announced to you thirty nine and by him all that believe are justified from all things from which ye were not able to be justified by the law of Moses forty Beware therefore lest that come upon you which is spoken in the prophets forty one Behold ye despisers and wonder and perish Because I work a work in your days A work which ye will not believe Though one should fully declare it to you forty two And as they were going out they besought that these words might be spoken to them on the next sabbath forty three And when the congregation was broken up many of the Jews and of the proselyte worshipers followed Paul and Barnabas who speaking to them persuaded them to continue in the grace of God forty four And on the next sabbath day almost the whole city came together to hear the word of God forty five But the Jews seeing the multitudes were filled with indignation and spoke against the things said by Paul contradicting and blaspheming forty six Then Paul and Barnabas spoke boldly and said It was necessary that the word of God should first be spoken to you but since ye thrust it from you and judge yourselves not worthy of the eternal life lo we turn to the Gentiles forty seven For so has the Lord commanded us I have set thee for a light of the Gentiles That thou shouldst be for salvation to the end of the earth forty eight And the Gentiles hearing it rejoiced and glorified the word of the Lord and as many as were appointed unto eternal life believed forty nine And the word of the Lord was spread abroad throughout all the region fifty But the Jews stirred up the devout and honorable women and the chief men of the city and raised persecution against Paul and Barnabas and drove them out from their borders fifty one And they having shaken off the dust of their feet against them came to Iconium fifty two And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit XIV AND it came to pass in Iconium that they went together into the synagogue of the Jews and so spoke that a great multitude both of Jews and Greeks believed two But the Jews who disbelieved stirred up and embittered the minds of the Gentiles against the brethren three They spent a long time therefore speaking boldly in the Lord who gave testimony to the word of his grace granting signs and wonders to be done by their hands four But the multitude of the city was divided and part held with the Jews and part with the apostles five And when a movement was made both of the Gentiles and Jews with their rulers to abuse and stone them six they being aware of it fled to the cities of Lycaonia Lystra and Derbe and the region around seven and there they were publishing the good news eight And there sat a certain man at Lystra impotent in his feet being lame from his mother s womb who never walked nine This man was listening to Paul as he spoke who fixing his eyes on him and perceiving that he had faith to be healed ten said with a loud voice Stand upright on thy feet And he leaped up and walked eleven And the multitudes seeing what Paul did lifted up their voices saying in the speech of Lycaonia The gods are come down to us in the likeness of men twelve And they called Barnabas Jupiter and Paul Mercury because he was the chief speaker thirteen And the priest of Jupiter that was before the city having brought oxen and garlands to the gates would have offered sacrifice with the people fourteen But the apostles Barnabas and Paul hearing of it rent their clothes and rushed forth to the multitude crying out fifteen and saying Sirs why do ye these things We also are men of like nature with you bringing you glad tidings that ye should turn from these vanities to the living God who made heaven and earth and the sea and all things that are therein sixteen who in the ages past suffered all nations to walk in their own ways seventeen although he left not himself without witness in that he did good giving you rain from heaven and fruitful seasons filling your hearts with food and gladness eighteen And with these sayings they hardly restrained the people from sacrificing to them nineteen But there came thither Jews from Antioch and Iconium and having persuaded the people and stoned Paul they drew him out of the city supposing that he was dead twenty But the disciples having gathered around him he rose up and came into the city and on the morrow he departed with Barnabas to Derbe twenty one And having published the good news to that city and made many disciples they turned back to Lystra and Iconium and Antioch twenty two confirming the souls of the disciples exhorting them to continue in the faith and that we must through much affliction enter into the kingdom of God twenty three And having appointed for them elders in every church they commended them with prayer and fasting to the Lord on whom they believed twenty four And after passing through Pisidia they came to Pamphylia twenty five And having spoken the word in Perga they went down to Attalia twenty six and thence they sailed away to Antioch from whence they had been commended to the grace of God for the work which they accomplished twenty seven And having come and gathered the church together they reported how great things God wrought with them and that he opened to the Gentiles a door of faith twenty eight And they spent no little time with the disciples XV AND certain men coming down from Judaea taught the brethren Except ye are circumcised after the custom of Moses ye can not be saved two Paul and Barnabas having therefore had no little dissension and discussion with them they determined that Paul and Barnabas and certain others of them should go up to Jerusalem to the apostles and elders about this question three They therefore having been sent forward by the church passed through Phoenicia and Samaria declaring the conversion of the Gentiles and they caused great joy to all the brethren four And having come to Jerusalem they were gladly received by the church and the apostles and elders and they reported how great things God wrought with them five But there arose some of those from the sect of the Pharisees who believed saying It is necessary to circumcise them and to command them to keep the law of Moses six And the apostles and the elders came together to consider this matter seven And when there had been much discussion Peter arose and said to them Men brethren ye know that a long time ago God made choice among us that by my mouth the Gentiles should hear the word of the glad tidings and believe eight And God who knows the heart bore them witness giving to them the Holy Spirit as also to us nine and made no difference between us and them purifying their hearts by faith ten Now therefore why do ye tempt God by putting a yoke upon the neck of the disciples which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear eleven But through the grace of the Lord Jesus we believe that we shall be saved in the same manner as they also twelve And all the multitude became silent and listened to Barnabas and Paul narrating how great signs and wonders God wrought among the Gentiles through them thirteen And after they were silent James answered saying Men brethren hearken to me fourteen Simeon narrated how at first God visited the Gentiles to take out of them a people for his name fifteen And with this agree the words of the prophets as it is written sixteen After this I will return And will rebuild the tabernacle of David which is fallen down And I will rebuild the ruins thereof and will set it up again seventeen that the rest of men may seek after the Lord And all the Gentiles upon whom my name has been called Saith the Lord who does these things fifteen seventeen eighteen Known to God are all his works from the beginning of the world nineteen Wherefore my judgment is that we trouble not those who from among the Gentiles are turning to God twenty but that we write to them that they abstain from pollutions of idols and from fornication and from what is strangled and from blood twenty one For Moses of old time has in every city those who preach him being read in the synagogues every sabbath twenty two Then the apostles and the elders with the whole church resolved having chosen men from themselves to send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas namely Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas leading men among the brethren twenty three And they wrote by them thus The apostles and the elders and the brethren to the brethren from the Gentiles throughout Antioch and Syria and Cilicia greeting twenty four Forasmuch as we heard that some who went out from us troubled you with words subverting your souls saying that ye must be circumcised and keep the law fifteen twenty four to whom we gave no commandment twenty five it seemed good to us having become of one mind to choose men and send them to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul twenty six men who have hazarded their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ twenty seven We have sent therefore Judas and Silas who will themselves also by word tell you the same things twenty eight For it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay upon you no further burden except these necessary things twenty nine that ye abstain from things offered to idols and from blood and from what is strangled and from fornication from which if ye keep yourselves ye will do well Farewell thirty They therefore being dismissed came to Antioch and assembling the multitude they delivered the letter thirty one And having read it they rejoiced for the consolation thirty two And Judas and Silas also themselves being prophets exhorted the brethren with many words and confirmed them thirty three And having remained a while they were dismissed with peace from the brethren to the apostles thirty four But it pleased Silas to abide there still fifteen thirty four thirty five Paul also and Barnabas continued in Antioch teaching and publishing the glad tidings of the word of the Lord with many others also thirty six And some days after Paul said to Barnabas Let us return now and visit the brethren in every city where we preached the word of the Lord and see how they do thirty seven And Barnabas determined to take with them John who was surnamed Mark thirty eight But Paul thought it proper not to take with them him who departed from them from Pamphylia and went not with them to the work thirty nine And there arose a sharp contention so that they parted one from the other and Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus forty And Paul having chosen Silas went forth being commended by the brethren to the grace of God forty one And he went through Syria and Cilicia confirming the churches XVI AND he came down to Derbe and Lystra And behold a certain disciple was there named Timothy the son of a believing Jewish woman but whose father was a Greek two who was well reported of by the brethren in Lystra and Iconium three Him Paul wished to go forth with him and took and circumcised him on account of the Jews who were in those places for they all knew that his father was a Greek four And as they journeyed through the cities they delivered to them the decrees to keep that were ordained by the apostles and elders who were in Jerusalem five The churches therefore were established in the faith and increased in number daily six And having gone through the region of Phrygia and Galatia and being forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia seven they came to Mysia and attempted to go into Bithynia but the Spirit of Jesus did not permit them eight And passing by Mysia they came down to Troas nine And a vision appeared to Paul in the night There stood a man a Macedonian beseeching him and saying Come over into Macedonia and help us ten And when he had seen the vision immediately we sought to go into Macedonia concluding that the Lord had called us to publish the good news to them eleven Therefore setting sail from Troas we ran with a straight course to Samothrace and on the following day to Neapolis twelve and from thence to Philippi which is a chief city of that part of Macedonia a colony And we continued in that city certain days thirteen And on the sabbath we went forth out of the gate by a river side where was wont to be a place of prayer and we sat down and spoke to the women who came together fourteen And a certain woman named Lydia a seller of purple of the city of Thyatira who worshiped God was listening whose heart the Lord opened to attend to the things spoken by Paul fifteen And when she was immersed and her household she besought us saying If ye have judged me to be a believer in the Lord come into my house and abide And she constrained us sixteen And it came to pass as we were going to the place of prayer a certain bondmaid having a spirit of divination met us who brought her masters much gain by soothsaying seventeen She having followed Paul and us cried saying These men are the servants of the most high God who announce to us the way of salvation eighteen And this she did many days But Paul being indignant sixteen eighteen turned and said to the spirit I command thee in the name of Jesus Christ to come out from her And he came out the same hour nineteen And her masters seeing that the hope of their gain departed laid hold of Paul and Silas and drew them into the market place before the rulers twenty And having brought them to the magistrates they said These men being Jews greatly disturb our city twenty one and teach customs which it is not lawful for us to receive or to observe being Romans twenty two And the multitude rose up together against them and the magistrates rent off their clothes and commanded to beat them with rods twenty three And having laid many stripes on them they cast them into prison charging the jailer to keep them safely twenty four who having received such a charge thrust them into the inner prison and made their feet fast in the stocks twenty five And at midnight Paul and Silas prayed and sang praises to God and the prisoners listened to them twenty six And suddenly there was a great earthquake so that the foundations of the prison were shaken and immediately all the doors were opened and the chains of all were loosed twenty seven And the jailer awaking out of sleep and seeing the prison doors open drew his sword and was about to kill himself supposing that the prisoners had fled twenty eight But Paul cried with a loud voice saying Do thyself no harm for we are all here twenty nine And calling for lights he sprang in and trembling fell down before Paul and Silas thirty and having brought them out he said Sirs what must I do to be saved thirty one And they said Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ and thou shalt be saved and thy house thirty two And they spoke to him the word of the Lord and to all that were in his house thirty three And taking them along the same hour of the night he washed their stripes and was immersed himself and all his immediately thirty four And having brought them up into his house he set food before them and rejoiced with all his house believing in God thirty five And when it was day the magistrates sent the sergeants saying Let those men go thirty six And the keeper of the prison reported these words to Paul The magistrates have sent to let you go now therefore depart and go in peace thirty seven But Paul said to them They beat us openly uncondemned being Romans and cast us into prison and now do they send us forth secretly Nay verily but let them come themselves and bring us out thirty eight And the sergeants reported these words to the magistrates and they were afraid when they heard that they were Romans thirty nine And they came and besought them and bringing them out entreated them to depart out of the city forty And they went out of the prison and entered into the house of Lydia and seeing the brethren they exhorted them and departed XVII AND passing through Amphipolis and Apollonia they came to Thessalonica where was the synagogue of the Jews two And Paul as his custom was went in to them and for three sabbaths reasoned with them from the Scriptures three opening them and setting forth that the Christ must suffer and rise again from the dead and that this is the Christ Jesus whom I preach to you four And some of them believed and joined themselves to seventeen four Paul and Silas and of the devout Greeks a great multitude and of the chief women not a few five But the Jews moved with envy seventeen five having taken to them of the idlers in the market place certain vicious men and having gathered a crowd set the city in an uproar and assaulting the house of Jason they sought to bring them unto the people six And not finding them they dragged Jason and certain brethren before the rulers of the city crying These that have turned the world upside down are come hither also seven Whom Jason has received and all these are acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar saying that there is another king Jesus eight And they troubled the people and the rulers of the city when they heard these things nine And having taken security of Jason and of the others they let them go ten And the brethren immediately sent away Paul and Silas by night to Beroea who coming thither went into the synagogue of the Jews eleven These were more noble than those in Thessalonica in that they received the word with all readiness and searched the Scriptures daily whether these things were so twelve Many of them therefore believed and of honorable Grecian women and men not a few thirteen But when the Jews of Thessalonica knew that also at Beroea the word of God was preached by Paul they came stirring up the people there also fourteen And then immediately the brethren sent away Paul to journey as upon the sea but Silas and Timothy abode there still fifteen And they who conducted Paul brought him to Athens and having received a command to Silas and Timothy to come to him as soon as possible they departed sixteen Now while Paul was waiting for them at Athens his spirit was stirred in him when he saw the city full of idols seventeen Therefore he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and the devout persons and in the market daily with those who met with him eighteen And certain philosophers of the Epicureans and of the Stoics were disputing with him And some said What would this babbler say and others He seems to be a proclaimer of foreign gods because he made known to them the good news of Jesus and the resurrection nineteen And taking hold of him they brought him upon Mars Hill saying May we know what this new doctrine is of which thou speakest twenty For thou bringest certain strange things to our ears we would know therefore what these things mean twenty one Now all Athenians and the strangers residing there spent their leisure for nothing else but to tell or to hear something new twenty two And Paul standing in the midst of Mars Hill said Men of Athens in all things I perceive that ye are very devout twenty three For as I passed by and observed your objects of worship I found also an altar with this inscription TO AN UNKNOWN GOD Whom therefore not knowing ye worship him I announce to you twenty four The God who made the world and all things therein he being Lord of heaven and earth dwells not in temples made with hands twenty five nor is ministered to by human hands as if needing anything more himself giving to all life and breath and all things twenty six And he made of one blood every nation of men to dwell on all the face of the earth having fixed the appointed seasons and bounds of their habitation twenty seven that they should seek the Lord if haply they might feel after him and find him although he is not far from every one of us twenty eight for in him we live and move and have our being as also some of your own poets have said For his offspring also are we twenty nine Being therefore God s offspring we ought not to think that the Godhead is like to gold or silver or stone graven by art and man s device thirty The times of ignorance therefore God overlooked but now commands all men everywhere to repent thirty one Because he fixed a day in which he will judge the world in righteousness by the man whom he appointed having given assurance to all by raising him from the dead thirty two And when they heard of a resurrection of the dead some mocked and others said We will hear thee again of this matter thirty three And thus Paul departed from among them thirty four But certain ones joining themselves to him believed among whom was also Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them XVIII AFTER these things Paul departed from Athens and came to Corinth two And finding a certain Jew named Aquila a native of Pontus lately come from Italy and Priscilla his wife because Claudius had commanded all the Jews to depart from Rome he came to them three and because he was of the same trade he abode with them and labored for by their occupation they were tentmakers four And he reasoned in the synagogue every sabbath and persuaded both Jews and Greeks five And when Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia Paul was engrossed with the word testifying to the Jews that Jesus is the Christ six But they opposing themselves and blaspheming he shook out his garments and said to them Your blood be upon your own head I am clean from henceforth I will go to the Gentiles seven And departing thence he entered into a certain man s house named Justus one who worshiped God whose house was adjoining the synagogue eight And Crispus the ruler of the synagogue believed on the Lord with all his house and many of the Corinthians hearing believed and were immersed nine And the Lord said to Paul through a vision in the night Be not afraid but speak and hold not thy peace ten for I am with thee and no one shall assail thee to hurt thee for I have much people in this city eleven And he continued there a year and six months teaching the word of God among them twelve And when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia the Jews rose up with one accord against Paul and brought him before the judgment seat thirteen saying This man persuades men to worship God contrary to the law fourteen And as Paul was about to open his mouth Gallio said to the Jews If it were some injustice or wicked misdeed O Jews with reason I would have borne with you fifteen But if it is a question about a word and names and your own law look to it yourselves I will not be a judge of these things sixteen And he drove them away from the judgment seat seventeen But having all seized upon Sosthenes the ruler of the synagogue they beat him before the judgment seat And Gallio cared for none of these things eighteen And Paul having remained yet many days took leave of the brethren and sailed thence to Syria and with him Priscilla and Aquila having shaven his head in Cenchrea for he had a vow nineteen And they came to Ephesus and he left them there but entering himself into the synagogue he reasoned with the Jews twenty And they desiring him to remain a longer time with them he consented not twenty one but took leave of them saying eighteen twenty one I must by all means keep the coming feast at Jerusalem but I will return again to you if God will And he sailed from Ephesus twenty two And having landed at Caesarea and gone up and saluted the church he went down to Antioch twenty three And after he had spent some time there he departed going through the country of Galatia and Phrygia in order strengthening all the disciples twenty four And a certain Jew named Apollos a native of Alexandria an eloquent man and mighty in the Scriptures came to Ephesus twenty five This man was instructed in the way of the Lord and being fervent in spirit he spoke and taught correctly the things concerning Jesus knowing only the immersion of John twenty six And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue But Aquila and Priscilla having heard him took him to them and expounded to him the way of God more perfectly twenty seven And he wishing to pass through into Achaia the brethren wrote exhorting the disciples to receive him who when he was come contributed much to those who had believed through grace twenty eight For he powerfully confuted the Jews in public showing by the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ XIX AND it came to pass that while Apollos was at Corinth Paul having passed through the upper districts came to Ephesus And finding certain disciples two he said to them Did ye receive the Holy Spirit when ye believed And they said to him Nay we did not even hear whether there is a Holy Spirit three And he said to them Unto what then were ye immersed And they said Unto John s immersion four Then said Paul John indeed immersed with the immersion of repentance saying to the people that they should believe on him who should come after him that is on Jesus five And when they heard this they were immersed in the name of the Lord Jesus six And Paul having laid his hands upon them the Holy Spirit came on them and they spoke with tongues and prophesied seven And all the men were about twelve eight And he went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for three months reasoning and persuading them of the things concerning the kingdom of God nine But when some were hardened and believed not speaking evil of the Way before the multitude he departed from them and separated the disciples reasoning daily in the school of Tyrannus ten And this continued for two years so that all who dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord both Jews and Greeks eleven And God wrought special miracles by the hands of Paul twelve so that also there were carried from his body to the sick handkerchiefs or aprons and the diseases departed from them and the evil spirits went out from them thirteen Then some of the wandering Jewish exorcists took upon them to name over those who had the evil spirits the name of the Lord Jesus saying I adjure you by the Jesus whom Paul preaches fourteen And there were seven sons of one Sceva a Jewish chief priest who did this fifteen And the evil spirit answering said Jesus I know and Paul I well know but who are ye sixteen And the man in whom the evil spirit was leaped on them and overcame them and prevailed against both so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded seventeen And this became known to all both Jews and Greeks who dwelt at Ephesus and fear fell on them all and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified eighteen And many of the believers came confessing and declaring their deeds nineteen Many of those also who practiced curious arts brought together the books and burned them before all and they counted the price of them and found it fifty thousand pieces of silver twenty So mightily grew the word of God and prevailed twenty one When these things were ended Paul purposed to go to Jerusalem passing through Macedonia and Achaia saying After I have been there I must also see Rome twenty two And having sent into Macedonia two of those who ministered to him Timothy and Erastus he himself stayed in Asia for a season twenty three And about that time there arose no small tumult concerning the Way twenty four For a certain man named Demetrius a silversmith who made silver shrines of Diana brought no small gain to the craftsmen twenty five whom he called together with the workmen of like occupation and said Sirs ye well know that by this craft we have our wealth twenty six Moreover ye see and hear that this Paul has persuaded and turned aside much people not only of Ephesus but of almost all Asia saying that they are not gods which are made with hands twenty seven And there is danger to us not only that this branch of business will come into disrepute but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana will be accounted nothing and her magnificence will be destroyed whom all Asia and the world worship twenty eight And hearing it they became full of wrath and continued crying out saying Great is Diana of the Ephesians twenty nine And the whole city was filled with confusion and they rushed with one accord into the theatre having seized Gaius and Aristarchus men of Macedonia Paul s companions in travel thirty And Paul wishing to enter in unto the people the disciples suffered him not thirty one And some also of the chiefs of Asia being his friends sent to him entreating him not to adventure himself into the theatre thirty two Some therefore were crying one thing and some another for the assembly was confused and the greater part knew not wherefore they had come together thirty three And they brought forward Alexander out of the multitude the Jews thrusting him forward And Alexander beckoned with the hand desiring to make his defense to the people thirty four But when they knew that he was a Jew one voice arose from all crying about two hours Great is Diana of the Ephesians thirty five And the town clerk having quieted the people said Men of Ephesus what human being is there who knows not that the city of the Ephesians is keeper of the great Diana and of the image which fell down from Jupiter thirty six These things being therefore undeniable ye ought to be quiet and to do nothing rashly thirty seven For ye brought hither these men who are neither robbers of temples nor blasphemers of your goddess thirty eight If therefore Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a matter against any man the law is open nineteen thirty eight and there are proconsuls let them implead one another thirty nine But if ye make any demand concerning other matters it shall be determined in the lawful assembly forty For we are in danger of being called in question for this day s riot there being no cause whereby we may give an account of this concourse forty one And having thus spoken he dismissed the assembly XX AND after the tumult ceased Paul called to him the disciples and having embraced them departed to go into Macedonia two And having gone through those regions and given them much exhortation he came into Greece three And after he had stayed three months a plot being laid for him by the Jews as he was about sailing to Syria it was resolved that he should return through Macedonia four And there accompanied him unto Asia Sopater son of Pyrrhus a Beroean and of the Thessalonians Aristarchus and Secundus and Gaius of Derbe and Timothy and of Asia Tychicus and Trophimus five These having gone forward were waiting for us at Troas six But we sailed forth from Philippi after the days of unleavened bread and came to them to Troas in five days where we abode seven days seven And on the first day of the week we having come together to break bread Paul discoursed to them being about to depart on the morrow and continued the discourse until midnight eight Now there were many lights in the upper room where we were assembled nine And there sat on the window a certain young man named Eutychus being fallen into a deep sleep and as Paul was long discoursing he sunk down with sleep and fell down from the third loft and was taken up dead ten And Paul went down and fell on him and embracing him said Do not lament for his life is in him eleven And having come up again and broken the bread and eaten he talked a long while even till break of day and so departed twelve And they brought the young man living and were not a little comforted thirteen And we going forward to the ship embarked for Assos intending there to take in Paul for so he had appointed intending himself to go on foot fourteen And when he met with us at Assos we took him in and came to Mitylene fifteen And sailing thence we came the following day over against Chios and the next day we arrived at Samos and having tarried at Trogyllium we came the next day to Miletus sixteen For Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus that he might not spend time in Asia for he was hastening if it were possible for him to be at Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost seventeen And from Miletus he sent to Ephesus and called the elders of the church eighteen And when they were come to him he said to them Ye know from the first day that I came into Asia after what manner I have been with you the whole time nineteen serving the Lord with all lowliness of mind and with tears and trials which befell me by the plottings of the Jews twenty how I kept back nothing that was profitable that I should not announce it to you and teach you publicly and from house to house twenty one testifying to both Jews and Greeks repentance toward God and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ twenty two And now behold I go bound in the spirit to Jerusalem not knowing the things that shall befall me there twenty three save that the Holy Spirit witnesses to me in every city saying that bonds and afflictions await me twenty four But none of these things move me neither do I count my life dear to myself so that I may finish my course with joy twenty twenty four and the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus to testify the good news of the grace of God twenty five And now behold I know that all ye among whom I went about preaching the kingdom of God shall see my face no more twenty six Wherefore I testify to you this day that I am pure from the blood of all twenty seven for I shunned not to declare to you the whole counsel of God twenty eight Take heed therefore to yourselves and to all the flock in which the Holy Spirit made you overseers to feed the church of the Lord twenty twenty eight which he purchased with his own blood twenty nine For I know this that after my departure grievous wolves will enter in among you not sparing the flock thirty And from among yourselves will men arise speaking perverse things to draw away disciples after them thirty one Therefore watch remembering that for the space of three years night and day I ceased not to warn every one with tears thirty two And now brethren I commend you to God and to the word of his grace who is able to build you up and to give you an inheritance among all the sanctified thirty three I coveted no one s silver or gold or apparel thirty four Ye yourselves know that these hands ministered to my necessities and to those who were with me thirty five In all ways I showed you that so laboring ye ought to assist the weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus that he himself said It is more blessed to give than to receive thirty six And having thus spoken he kneeled down and prayed with them all thirty seven And they all wept sorely and fell on Paul s neck and kissed him thirty eight sorrowing most of all for the word which he had spoken that they should behold his face no more And they accompanied him to the ship XXI AND it came to pass that after we had torn ourselves from them and had put to sea we came with a straight course to Coos and the day following to Rhodes and from thence to Patara two And finding a ship crossing over to Phoenicia we went aboard and put to sea three And bringing Cyprus in sight and leaving it on the left hand we sailed to Syria and landed at Tyre for there the ship was to unlade her burden four And having found out the disciples we remained there seven days who said to Paul through the Spirit that he should not go up to Jerusalem five And when we had completed the days we departed and went our way they all accompanying us with wives and children till we were out of the city and we kneeled down on the beach and prayed six And having embraced one another we went on board the ship and they returned to their homes seven And we completing the voyage came down from Tyre to Ptolemais and having embraced the brethren we remained with them one day eight And on the morrow we departed and came to Caesarea and entering into the house of Philip the evangelist being one of the Seven we abode with him nine And this man had four daughters virgins who prophesied ten And while we were remaining several days there came down from Judaea a certain prophet named Agabus eleven And coming to us he took off Paul s girdle and bound his own hands and feet and said Thus says the Holy Spirit So will the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man whose this girdle is and will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles twelve And when we heard these things both we and they of that place besought him not to go up to Jerusalem thirteen Then answered Paul What mean ye to weep and to break my heart For I am ready not only to be bound but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus fourteen And when he would not be persuaded we ceased saying The will of the Lord be done fifteen And after those days having packed up our baggage we went up to Jerusalem sixteen There went with us also some of the disciples from Caesarea bringing us to Mnason of Cyprus an old disciple with whom we should lodge seventeen And when we were come to Jerusalem the brethren received us gladly eighteen And on the following day Paul went in with us to James and all the elders were present nineteen And having embraced them he recounted particularly what things God had wrought among the Gentiles through his ministry twenty And they hearing it glorified the Lord And they said to him Thou seest brother how many thousands of Jews there are who believe and they are all zealots for the law twenty one And they were informed concerning thee that thou teachest all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses saying that they should not circumcise their children nor walk after the customs twenty two What is it therefore A multitude must surely come together for they will hear that thou hast come twenty three Do therefore this that we say to thee We have four men who have a vow on them twenty four these take with thee and purify thyself with them and bear the charges for them that they may shave their heads and all will know that those things of which they have been informed concerning thee are nothing but that thou thyself also walkest orderly keeping the law twenty five But concerning the Gentiles who have believed we wrote to them deciding that they should observe no such thing except that they keep themselves from things offered to idols and from blood and from what is strangled and from fornication twenty six Then Paul took the men and the next day having purified himself with them entered into the temple announcing the completion of the days of the purification until the offering was brought for each one of them twenty seven And as the seven days were about to be completed the Jews from Asia having observed him in the temple stirred up all the people and laid hands on him twenty eight crying out Men of Israel help This is the man who teaches all everywhere against the people and the law and this place and further also he brought Greeks into the temple and has polluted this holy place twenty nine For they had before seen with him in the city Trophimus the Ephesian whom they supposed that Paul brought into the temple thirty And all the city was moved and the people ran together and laying hold of Paul they dragged him out of the temple and forthwith the doors were shut thirty one And while they were seeking to kill him a report came up to the chief captain of the band that all Jerusalem was in an uproar thirty two who immediately took with him soldiers and centurions and ran down to them and they seeing the chief captain and the soldiers left off beating Paul thirty three Then the chief captain came near and took hold of him and commanded him to be bound with two chains and inquired who he was and what he had done thirty four And some cried one thing some another among the multitude and not being able to know the certainty on account of the tumult he commanded him to be led into the castle thirty five And when he came upon the stairs so it was that he was borne by the soldiers on account of the violence of the people thirty six For the multitude of the people followed after crying Away with him thirty seven And as he was about to be led into the castle Paul says to the chief captain May I speak to thee And he said Canst thou speak Greek thirty eight Art thou not then the Egyptian who before these days made an uproar and led out into the wilderness the four thousand men of the assassins thirty nine And Paul said I am a Jew of Tarsus a citizen of no obscure city of Cilicia and I beseech thee suffer me to speak to the people forty And he having given him permission Paul standing on the stairs beckoned with the hand to the people And a great silence ensuing he spoke to them in the Hebrew tongue saying XXII BRETHREN and fathers hear my defense which I now make to you two And hearing that he spoke to them in the Hebrew tongue they kept the more silence three And he says I am a Jew born indeed in Tarsus of Cilicia but brought up in this city taught at the feet of Gamaliel according to the strictness of the law of the fathers being zealous for God as ye all are this day four And I persecuted this Way unto death binding and delivering into prisons both men and women five As also the high priest bears me witness and all the eldership from whom moreover I received letters to the brethren and was journeying to Damascus to bring also those who were there bound to Jerusalem that they might be punished six And it came to pass that as I journeyed and came near to Damascus about midday there suddenly flashed around me a great light out of heaven seven And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me Saul Saul why persecutest thou me eight And I answered Who art thou Lord And he said to me I am Jesus the Nazarene whom thou persecutest nine And they who were with me beheld indeed the light and were afraid but the voice of him who spoke to me they heard not twenty two nine ten And I said What shall I do Lord And the Lord said to me Arise and go into Damascus and there it shall be told thee concerning all things which it is appointed thee to do eleven And as I could not see for the glory of that light being led by the hand by those who were with me I came into Damascus twelve And one Ananias a devout man according to the law having a good report from all the Jews who dwelt there thirteen came to me and standing by me said to me Brother Saul receive sight And I in that very hour looked up upon him fourteen And he said The God of our fathers appointed thee to know his will and to see the Just One and to hear a voice out of his mouth fifteen For thou shalt be a witness for him to all men of what thou hast seen and didst hear sixteen And now why tarriest thou Arise be immersed and wash away thy sins calling on his name seventeen And it came to pass when I had returned to Jerusalem and as I was praying in the temple that I was in a trance eighteen and saw him saying to me Make haste and go forth quickly out of Jerusalem for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me nineteen And I said Lord they well know that I imprisoned and beat in every synagogue those who believe on thee twenty and when the blood of thy witness Stephen was shed then I myself was standing by and consenting and keeping the garments of those who slew him twenty one And he said to me Depart for I will send thee far hence to the Gentiles twenty two And they heard him unto this word and then lifted up their voices and said Away with such a one from the earth for it was not fit that he should live twenty three And as they were crying out and throwing up their garments and casting dust into the air twenty four the chief captain commanded him to be brought into the castle and bade that he should be examined by scourging that he might know for what charge they were thus crying out against him twenty five And as they stretched him forth with the thongs twenty two twenty five Paul said to the centurion who stood by Is it lawful for you to scourge a man that is a Roman and uncondemned twenty six The centurion hearing it he went and told the chief captain saying What art thou about to do For this man is a Roman twenty seven And the chief captain came and said to him Tell me art thou a Roman He said Yes twenty eight And the chief captain answered For a great sum I obtained this freedom And Paul said But I was born free twenty nine Immediately therefore they departed from him who were about to examine him and the chief captain also was afraid after he knew that he was a Roman and because he had bound him thirty On the morrow wishing to know the certainty wherefore he was accused by the Jews he released him and commanded the chief priests and all the council to come together and he brought Paul down and set him before them XXIII AND Paul earnestly beholding the council said Men brethren I have lived in all good conscience before God unto this day two And the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by him to smite him on the mouth three Then Paul said to him God will smite thee thou whited wall And dost thou sit to judge me according to the law and command me to be smitten contrary to law four And they that stood by said Revilest thou God s high priest five And Paul said I knew not brethren that he is high priest for it is written Thou shalt not speak evil of a ruler of thy people six And Paul knowing that the one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees cried out in the council Men brethren I am a Pharisee the son of a Pharisee for the hope of the resurrection of the dead I am now judged seven And when he had said this there arose a dissension between the Pharisees and the Sadducees and the multitude was divided eight For Sadducees say that there is no resurrection nor angel nor spirit but Pharisees acknowledge both nine And there arose a great clamor and the scribes of the party of the Pharisees arose and contended saying We find no evil in this man but if a spirit spoke to him or an angel ten And a great dissension arising the chief captain fearing lest Paul should be pulled in pieces by them commanded the soldiery to go down and to take him by force from among them and to bring him into the castle eleven And the night following the Lord stood by him and said Be of good courage for as thou didst fully testify the things concerning me at Jerusalem so must thou testify also at Rome twelve And when it was day the Jews banded together and bound themselves under a curse saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul thirteen And they were more than forty who made this conspiracy fourteen And they came to the chief priests and the elders and said We bound ourselves under a great curse to taste nothing until we have slain Paul fifteen Now therefore do ye with the council signify to the chief captain that he bring him down to you as though ye would ascertain more exactly the matters concerning him and we before he comes near are ready to kill him sixteen And the son of Paul s sister hearing of their lying in wait went and entered into the castle and told Paul seventeen Then Paul called one of the centurions to him and said Bring this young man to the chief captain for he has something to tell him eighteen So he took him and brought him to the chief captain and said Paul the prisoner called me to him and asked me to bring this young man to thee as he has something to say to thee nineteen Then the chief captain took him by the hand and went aside privately and asked What is that thou hast to tell me twenty And he said The Jews agreed to desire thee that thou wouldst bring down Paul to morrow into the council as though they would inquire somewhat more exactly concerning him twenty one But do not thou yield to them for of them more than forty men are lying in wait for him who bound themselves with an oath neither to eat nor to drink till they have killed him and now they are ready looking for the promise from thee twenty two The chief captain therefore dismissed the young man having charged him to say to no one that thou didst show these things to me twenty three And calling to him two or three of the centurions he said Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea and seventy horsemen two hundred spearmen at the third hour of the night twenty four and let them provide beasts that they may set Paul thereon and bring him safe to Felix the governor twenty five And he wrote a letter after this manner twenty six Claudius Lysias to the most excellent governor Felix sends greeting twenty seven This man was taken by the Jews and was about to be killed by them but I came upon them with the soldiery and rescued him having learned that he is a Roman twenty eight And wishing to know the crime for which they were accusing him I brought him down into their council twenty nine whom I found to be accused concerning questions of their law but having nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds thirty And being informed that a plot was about to be laid against the man I sent straightway to thee having also commanded the accusers to say before thee what they had against him Farewell thirty one The soldiers therefore as was commanded them took up Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris thirty two But on the morrow leaving the horsemen to go with him they returned to the castle thirty three who when they had entered into Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor presented Paul also before him thirty four And having read it he asked of what province he was And learning that he was from Cilicia thirty five he said I will hear thee fully when thy accusers are also come And he commanded him to be kept in the praetorium of Herod XXIV AND after five days the high priest Ananias came down with the elders and a certain orator named Tertullus who informed the governor against Paul two and he having been called Tertullus began to accuse him saying Seeing that by thee we enjoy great quietness and that very worthy deeds are done for this nation through thy providence in every way and everywhere three we accept it most noble Felix with all thankfulness four But not to hinder thee too long I pray thee that thou wouldst hear us of thy clemency a few words five For we have found this man to be a pest and exciting disturbance among all the Jews throughout the world and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes six who also attempted to profane the temple whom we took twenty four six and desired to judge according to our law seven But Lysias the chief captain came and with great violence took him away out of our hands eight commanding his accusers to come before thee from whom thou canst thyself ascertain by examination concerning all these things whereof we accuse him nine And the Jews also joined in assailing him saying that these things were so ten Then Paul the governor having beckoned to him to speak answered Knowing that thou hast been for many years a judge for this nation I do the more cheerfully answer for myself eleven inasmuch as thou mayest know that there are not more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship twelve and neither in the temple did they find me disputing with any one or causing a tumult of the people nor in the synagogues nor in the city thirteen nor can they prove the things whereof they now accuse me fourteen But this I acknowledge to thee that according to the way which they call a sect so I worship the God of our fathers believing all things which are written in the law and the prophets fifteen having a hope toward God which these themselves also look for that there will be a resurrection both of the just and unjust sixteen Therefore do I also myself strive to have always a conscience void of offense toward God and men seventeen And after many years I came to bring alms to my nation and offerings eighteen Amidst which they found me purified in the temple not with a crowd nor with tumult but certain Jews from Asia caused it nineteen who ought to be here before thee and make accusation if they had aught against me twenty Or let these themselves say what crime they found in me while I stood before the council twenty one except for this one voice that I cried standing among them Concerning the resurrection of the dead I am judged by you this day twenty two And Felix put them off knowing the things concerning the Way more accurately saying When Lysias the chief captain shall come down I will fully inquire into your matters twenty three And he commanded the centurion that he should be guarded and should have indulgence and to forbid none of his acquaintance to minister to him twenty four And after certain days Felix came with his wife Drusilla who was a Jewess and sent for Paul and heard him concerning the faith in Christ twenty five And as he reasoned of righteousness temperance and the judgment to come Felix trembled and answered Go thy way for this time when I have a convenient season I will call for thee twenty six He hoped also that money would be given him by Paul wherefore he sent for him the oftener and conversed with him twenty seven But after two years Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus and Felix wishing to gain favor with the Jews left Paul bound XXV FESTUS therefore having come into the province after three days went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem two And the high priest and the chief of the Jews informed him against Paul and besought him three asking for themselves a favor against him that he would send for him to Jerusalem preparing an ambush to slay him on the way four But Festus answered that Paul was to be kept a prisoner at Caesarea and that he himself should soon go thither five Let them therefore said he who are powerful among you go down with me and accuse this man if there is any wickedness in him six And having tarried among them not more than eight or ten days he went down to Caesarea and on the morrow sitting on the judgment seat he commanded Paul to be brought seven And when he was come the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around bringing many and grievous charges which they could not prove eight while Paul said in defense Neither against the law of the Jews nor against the temple nor against Caesar did I commit any offense nine But Festus wishing to gain favor with the Jews answered Paul and said Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem and there be judged concerning these things before me ten And Paul said I stand at Caesar s judgment seat where I ought to be judged To Jews I did no wrong as thou also very well knowest twenty five ten eleven If then I am an offender and have done anything worthy of death I refuse not to die but if there be none of the things whereof these accuse me no man can give me up to them I appeal to Caesar twelve Then Festus having conferred with the council answered Thou hast appealed to Caesar to Caesar thou shalt go thirteen And after certain days Agrippa the king and Bernice came to Caesarea to salute Festus fourteen And as they were spending some days there Festus laid the case of Paul before the king saying There is a certain man left in bonds by Felix fifteen about whom when I was at Jerusalem the chief priests and the elders of the Jews made complaint asking for judgment against him sixteen To whom I answered It is not a custom for Romans to give up any man before the accused has the accusers face to face and has opportunity to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him seventeen When therefore they had come together here without any delay on the morrow I sat on the judgment seat and commanded the man to be brought forth eighteen and standing up around him the accusers brought no accusation of such things as I supposed nineteen but had certain controversies with him concerning their own religion and concerning a certain Jesus who was dead whom Paul affirmed to be alive twenty And I being perplexed in regard to the dispute about these things asked whether he would go to Jerusalem and there be judged concerning them twenty one But Paul having appealed to be kept in custody for the decision of Augustus I commanded him to be kept until I shall send him up to Caesar twenty two And Agrippa said to Festus I would also hear the man myself To morrow said he thou shalt hear him twenty three On the morrow therefore Agrippa and Bernice having come with great pomp and entered into the place of hearing with the chief captains and principal men of the city at Festus command Paul was brought forth twenty four And Festus said King Agrippa and all men who are here present with us ye see this man about whom all the multitude of the Jews interceded with me both at Jerusalem and here Crying out that he ought not to live any longer twenty five But having found that he had committed nothing worthy of death and he himself having appealed to Augustus I determined to send him twenty six Of whom I have nothing certain to write to my lord Wherefore I brought him forth before you and specially before thee king Agrippa in order that the examination having been made I may have something to write twenty seven For it seems to me unreasonable to send a prisoner and not also signify the charges against him XXVI AND Agrippa said to Paul Thou art permitted to speak for thyself Then Paul stretched forth the hand and answered for himself two I think myself happy king Agrippa because I shall answer for myself before thee this day concerning all things whereof I am accused by Jews three especially since thou art expert in all the customs and questions among Jews Wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently four My manner of life therefore from my youth which was from the beginning among my own nation at Jerusalem all Jews know five having known me from the first if they were willing to testify that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee six And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made by God to the fathers seven unto which our twelve tribes earnestly serving day and night hope to attain concerning which hope O king I am accused by Jews eight Why is it judged incredible with you if God raises the dead nine I therefore thought to myself that I ought to do many hostile things against the name of Jesus the Nazarene ten Which I also did in Jerusalem and many of the saints did I myself shut up in prisons having received authority from the chief priests and when they were put to death I gave my voice against them eleven And punishing them often throughout all the synagogues I constrained them to blaspheme and being exceedingly mad against them I persecuted them also unto foreign cities twelve Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and a commission from the chief priests thirteen at midday O king I saw in the way a light from heaven above the brightness of the sun shining around me and those who journeyed with me fourteen And we all having fallen to the earth I heard a voice speaking to me and saying in the Hebrew tongue Saul Saul why persecutest thou me It is hard for thee to kick against the goads fifteen And I said Who art thou Lord And he said I am Jesus whom thou persecutest sixteen But arise and stand upon thy feet for I appeared to thee for this purpose to appoint thee a minister and a witness both of the things which thou sawest and of the things in which I will appear to thee seventeen delivering thee from the people and the Gentiles to whom I send thee eighteen to open their eyes that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan unto God that they may obtain forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among the sanctified by faith in me nineteen Wherefore O king Agrippa I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision twenty but to those in Damascus first and in Jerusalem and unto all the region of Judaea and to the Gentiles I announced that they should repent and turn to God doing works worthy of repentance twenty one For these causes the Jews seizing me in the temple attempted to kill me twenty two Having therefore obtained help from God I continue unto this day witnessing both to small and great saying nothing except those things which the prophets and Moses said should come twenty three whether the Christ should suffer whether he the first of the resurrection from the dead shall show light to the people and to the Gentiles twenty four And as he thus spoke for himself Festus said with a loud voice Paul thou art mad much learning makes thee mad twenty five But he said I am not mad most noble Festus but utter words of truth and soberness twenty six For the king knows well concerning these things to whom also I speak boldly for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him for this has not been done in a corner twenty seven King Agrippa believest thou the prophets I know that thou believest twenty eight And Agrippa said to Paul With little pains twenty six twenty eighta thou persuadest twenty six twenty eightb me to become a Christian twenty nine And Paul said I could pray God that with little or much twenty six twenty nine not only thou but also all that hear me this day may become such as I am except these bonds thirty And the king rose up and the governor and Bernice and they who sat with them thirty one And having withdrawn they talked together saying This man does nothing worthy of death or of bonds thirty two And Agrippa said to Festus This man could have been set at liberty if he had not appealed to Caesar XXVII AND when it was determined that we should sail to Italy they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners to a centurion named Julius of the Augustan band two And entering into a ship of Adramyttium about to sail along the coasts of Asia we put to sea Aristarchus a Macedonian of Thessalonica being with us three And on the second day we landed at Sidon And Julius treated Paul humanely and permitted him to go to his friends and receive their care four And thence having put to sea we sailed under Cyprus because the winds were contrary five And having sailed over the sea along Cilicia and Pamphylia we came to Myra a city of Lycia six And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing to Italy and he put us on board of it seven And sailing slowly many days and having come with difficulty over against Cnidus the wind not suffering us to put in twenty seven seven we sailed under Crete over against Salmone eight and coasting along it with difficulty we came to a certain place called Fair Havens near to which was the city Lasa nine And much time having been spent and the voyage being now dangerous because also the fast had already passed by Paul exhorted them ten saying Sirs I perceive that the voyage will be with violence and much loss not only of the lading and the ship but also of our lives eleven But the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship more than the things spoken by Paul twelve And as the haven was not well situated for wintering the greater number advised to sail thence also if by any means they might reach Phoenix a haven of Crete looking toward the southwest and northwest and there winter thirteen And a south wind beginning to blow moderately supposing that they had obtained their purpose they weighed anchor and coasted along close by Crete fourteen But not long after there struck against it a tempestuous wind called Euracylon fifteen And the ship being caught and unable to face the wind we yielded to it and were driven along sixteen And running under a certain small island called Clauda we were hardly able to come by the boat seventeen which when they had taken up they used helps undergirding the ship and fearing lest they should be cast away on the quicksand they lowered the sail and so were driven eighteen And we being violently tempest tossed the next day they lightened the ship nineteen and the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship twenty And neither sun nor stars appearing for many days and no small tempest lying on us thenceforward all hope that we should be saved was utterly taken away twenty one But after much abstinence then Paul standing up in the midst of then said Sirs ye should have hearkened to me and not put to sea from Crete and so have escaped this violence and loss twenty two And now I exhort you to be of good cheer for there shall be no loss of life among you but only of the ship twenty three For there stood by me this night an angel of God whose I am and whom I serve twenty four saying Fear not Paul thou must stand before Caesar and lo God has given thee all those who sail with thee twenty five Wherefore sirs be of good cheer for I believe God that it will be even so as it has been told me twenty six But we must be cast away upon a certain island twenty seven And when the fourteenth night was come as we were driven onward in the Adriatic sea about midnight the seamen suspected that they were near to some country twenty eight and sounding they found twenty fathoms and having gone a little further they sounded again and found fifteen fathoms twenty nine Then fearing lest we should fall upon rocks they cast four anchors out of the stern and wished for day thirty And as the seamen were seeking to flee out of the ship and had let down the boat into the sea under color as if they were about to extend anchors out of the foreship thirty one Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers Except these abide in the ship ye can not be saved thirty two Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat and let it fall off thirty three And while the day was coming on Paul besought them all to take food saying This day is the fourteenth day that ye have waited and continued fasting having taken nothing thirty four Wherefore I pray you to take food for this is for your safety for there shall not a hair fall from the head of one of you thirty five And having thus spoken he took bread and gave thanks to God in presence of them all and having broken it he began to eat thirty six Then were they all of good cheer and they also took food thirty seven And we were in all in the ship two hundred and seventy six souls thirty eight And when they had eaten enough they lightened the ship casting out the grain into the sea thirty nine And when it was day they knew not the land but they perceived a certain creek having a beach on which they determined if they were able to drive the ship ashore forty And cutting the anchors entirely away they abandoned them to the sea at the same time unfastening the bands of the rudders and hoisting the foresail to the wind they made toward the beach forty one And falling into a place where two seas met they ran the ship aground and the prow sticking fast remained immovable but the stern was broken by the violence of the waves forty two And it was the plan of the soldiers that they should kill the prisoners lest any one should swim out and escape forty three But the centurion wishing to save Paul kept them from their purpose and commanded that those who could swim should cast themselves first into the sea and get to land forty four and the rest some on boards and others on some of the pieces from the ship And so it came to pass that all escaped safe to land XXVIII AND having escaped they then learned that the island is called Melita two And the barbarians showed us no little kindness for they kindled a fire and received us all because of the present rain and because of the cold three And Paul having gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire there came out a viper from the heat and fastened on his hand four And when the barbarians saw the animal hanging from his hand they said among themselves No doubt this man is a murderer whom though escaped from the sea justice suffered not to live five He however shaking off the animal into the fire suffered no harm six But they were expecting that he would become inflamed or suddenly fall down dead but after looking a great while and seeing no harm befall him they changed their minds and said that he was a god seven In the region around that place there were lands of the chief man of the island whose name was Publius who received and entertained us kindly three days eight Now it happened that the father of Publius was lying sick with a fever and a bloody flux to whom Paul entered in and having prayed laid his hands on him and healed him nine And this having been done the others also who had diseases in the island came and were healed ten who also honored us with many honors and when we put to sea they loaded us with such things as were necessary eleven And after three months we put to sea in a ship of Alexandria which had wintered in the island whose sign was Castor and Pollux twelve And landing at Syracuse we remained three days thirteen And from thence making a circuit twenty eight thirteen we came to Rhegium And after one day a south wind arose and we came on the second day to Puteoli fourteen where we found brethren and were entreated to remain with them seven days and so we went toward Rome fifteen And from thence the brethren having heard of us came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and the Three Taverns whom when Paul saw he gave thanks to God and took courage sixteen And when we came to Rome the centurion delivered the prisoners to the commander of the camp but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with the soldier who guarded him seventeen And it came to pass that after three days Paul called together those who were the chief men of the Jews and when they were come together he said to them Men brethren though I had done nothing against the people or the customs of our fathers yet I was delivered a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans eighteen who when they had examined me wished to release me because there was no cause of death in me nineteen But as the Jews spoke against it I was compelled to appeal to Caesar not that I have anything to charge against my nation twenty For this cause therefore I called for you to see and to speak with you for on account of the hope of Israel I am compassed with this chain twenty one And they said to him We neither received letters from Judaea concerning thee nor did any one of the brethren that came report or speak any evil concerning thee twenty two But we desire to hear from thee what thou thinkest for concerning this sect we know that everywhere it is spoken against twenty three And having appointed a day for him they came to him in greater numbers to his lodging to whom he expounded testifying fully the kingdom of God and persuading them of the things concerning Jesus both from the law of Moses and the prophets from morning till evening twenty four And some believed the things spoken and some believed not twenty five And disagreeing among themselves they departed after Paul had spoken one word Well did the Holy Spirit speak through Isaiah the prophet to our fathers twenty six saying Go to this people and say With the hearing ye will hear and will not understand And seeing ye will see and will not perceive twenty seven For the heart of this people is become gross And their ears are dull of hearing And their eyes they have closed Lest haply they see with their eyes And hear with their ears And understand with their heart And turn and I shall heal them twenty eight Be it known to you therefore that to the Gentiles the salvation of God was sent they moreover will hear twenty eight twenty nine thirty And Paul remained two whole years in his own hired house and gladly received all that came in to him thirty one preaching the kingdom of God and teaching the things concerning the Lord Jesus Christ with all confidence no one hindering him THE LETTER OF PAUL TO THE ROMANS I PAUL a servant of Jesus Christ a called apostle set apart unto the gospel of God two which he before announced through his prophets in the Holy Scriptures three concerning his Son who was born of the seed of David according to the flesh four who was declared to be the Son of God with power according to the spirit of holiness by the resurrection from the dead Jesus Christ our Lord five through whom we received grace and apostleship for obedience to the faith among all the nations for his name s sake six among whom are ye also called of Jesus Christ seven to all the beloved of God that are in Rome called to be saints Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ eight First I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all that your faith is spoken of in all the world nine For God is my witness whom I serve in my spirit in the gospel of his Son how without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers ten making request if haply now at length I may be prospered by the will of God to come to you eleven For I long to see you that I may impart to you some spiritual gift to the end ye may be established twelve that is to be comforted together among you by each other s faith both yours and mine thirteen Now I would not have you ignorant brethren that often times I purposed to come to you but was hindered hitherto that I might have some fruit among you also as among the rest of the Gentiles fourteen I am debtor both to Greeks and Barbarians both to wise and unwise fifteen So as far as lies in me I am ready to preach the good news to you also who are at Rome sixteen For I am not ashamed of the gospel for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believes to the Jew first and also to the Greek seventeen For therein is revealed a righteousness of God from faith to faith as it is written The just shall live by faith eighteen For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who hold the truth in unrighteousness one eighteen nineteen because that which may be known of God is manifest in them for God manifested it to them twenty For from the creation of the world his invisible things are clearly seen being perceived by the things that are made even his eternal power and Godhead so that they are one twenty without excuse twenty one Because knowing God they glorified him not as God nor gave thanks but became vain in their reasonings and their foolish heart was darkened twenty two Professing themselves to be wise they became fools twenty three and changed the glory of the incorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man and to birds and fourfooted beasts and creeping things twenty four Wherefore God also gave them up in the lusts of their hearts to uncleanness to dishonor their bodies among themselves twenty five who changed the truth of God into a lie and worshiped and served the creature more than the Creator who is blessed forever Amen twenty six For this cause God gave them up to vile passions for their women changed the natural use into that which is against nature twenty seven and in like manner the men
